notes: A long-range lawman in a duster and patrol hat, sent to keep roads open, track raiders, and project NCR authority beyond the settled heartland.
The NCR’s elite field operator: seasoned, heavily trusted, and used for high-risk scouting, counter-raider work, and missions where experience matters more than comfort.
The backbone infantry—rifle, ration tin, and miles of marching—holding posts, manning checkpoints, and making the Republic feel real on the frontier.
Shock infantry in heavy armor built to hold chokepoints and push through firefights where a standard trooper would get shredded.
Scout-sniper trained to spot, range, and drop targets before they ever become a problem, usually operating ahead of columns or overwatching NCR positions.
Rare and valuable; when NCR aviation shows up it’s usually recon, transport, or a show of force—because fuel, parts, and politics keep most birds grounded.
The folks who police the uniform: discipline, desertion, contraband, and the ugly job of enforcing NCR rules on NCR soldiers.
An NCR-aligned frontier lawkeeper trying to make statutes matter in towns where ‘law’ used to be whoever had the biggest gun.
Day-to-day settlement policing—theft, brawls, curfews, and keeping order when locals would rather settle things with fists or knives.
The commissioned authority in the room: plans patrols, signs orders, and gets blamed when the supply line collapses or the outpost burns.
Keeper of rations, ammo, and spare parts—quietly one of the most powerful people in any camp, because logistics decides who fights and who starves.
Radios, flags, lamps, field phones—anything that turns chaos into coordination and keeps units from dying alone in the dust.
Collects rumors, questions prisoners, maps threats, and tries to predict tomorrow’s ambush from today’s scraps of information.
Builds and breaks: fortifications, bridges, mines, repairs, and the constant battle against sand, heat, and rust.
Keeps troopers breathing with field kits and chems, triaging fast because replacing soldiers is harder than replacing bandages.
The Republic’s paperwork made flesh—taxes, permits, courts, appointments—and the slow grind of turning wasteland into bureaucracy.
The symbol at the top of the Republic’s experiment: elected power, big promises, and responsibility for every flag planted too far from home.
Supreme authority (when recognized) over multiple chapters, shaping doctrine and deciding what technology is ‘salvation’ and what is ‘sin.’
Chapter leader controlling operations, the armory, and the chapter’s interpretation of the Brotherhood’s mission in their region.
Senior ideological authority guarding doctrine and unity as fiercely as any paladin guards a bunker door.
Keeper of ritual and belief—making sure the Brotherhood stays a *Brotherhood*, not just a gang with better armor.
Top-tier field commander or champion trusted with critical missions and the authority to act fast when protocol would get people killed.
Senior paladin overseeing combat forces, training standards, and the chapter’s ‘sharp end’ deployments.
A highly decorated paladin whose reputation sets the tone—when they speak, initiates listen.
Power-armored warfighter and leader tasked with recovering, securing, and—if needed—destroying technology that threatens humanity.
Senior specialist-administrator overseeing technical branches, research, logistics, or internal operations depending on chapter custom.
High-ranking knight leading major detachments and coordinating multi-squad operations under the Elder’s authority.
Officer leading squads/sections of knights, responsible for mission success and keeping expensive gear intact.
Core soldier-technician trained to fight, maintain equipment, and follow doctrine without asking too many questions.
Senior aviation leader where aircraft exist—coordinates flight operations, maintenance priorities, and mission tasking.
Aviation-qualified knight—pilot, crew, or flight specialist—trusted with machines the wasteland can’t easily replace.
Aircrew role tied to aircraft operations; prestige posting with brutal maintenance demands and zero margin for error.
Researcher, archivist, and engineer who catalogs tech, studies ruins, and keeps knowledge from turning into superstition.
Junior aide/apprentice assigned to learn under a knight or paladin—carrying gear, absorbing lessons, surviving the hard way.
New blood under training, proving discipline and competence before being trusted with the Brotherhood’s real toys.
A hopeful pushing to be accepted—close enough to taste the steel, not trusted enough to wear it.
The Caesar figure: absolute authority, shaping culture by will and law, with conquest framed as ‘order.’
Top battlefield commander empowered to drive campaigns forward and crush failure without mercy.
Veteran officer commanding forces in battle, feared for discipline and rewarded for results.
Elite bodyguards devoted to the supreme leader—trained to be the last wall between command and a blade.
Spies and infiltrators who gather intel, sabotage enemies, and manipulate politics while wearing someone else’s face.
A killer used where terror and precision matter more than numbers—quiet removals that keep enemies nervous.
Scout and pathfinder ranging ahead to find routes, water, and targets for the main force.
Freshly taken or newly indoctrinated—learning brutality, obedience, and survival under a banner that doesn’t tolerate weakness.
A proven frontline soldier—tougher, more experienced, expected to hold formation when others break.
Hardened by campaigns; often anchors fights and leads smaller groups through reputation and ruthlessness.
Small-unit leader responsible for keeping a squad cohesive, aggressive, and afraid enough to obey.
Handlers who train and control war dogs for tracking, intimidation, and ripping apart anyone who runs.
Standard-bearer and rally point—signals cohesion in the chaos and keeps the line from unraveling.
Elite guard rank tied to protection and enforcement duties close to command.
Maintains arms and armor in a war economy—repairing blades, forging spearheads, and keeping gear lethal.
Drill and indoctrination specialist who turns recruits into weapons through repetition, punishment, and doctrine.
The Enclave’s top authority: ‘continuity of government’ swagger wrapped in secrecy, protocol, and overwhelming firepower.
Second-in-command positioned to keep control if leadership falls—or if internal factions start sharpening knives.
Commands troops with old-world doctrine, coordinating armor, air, and strict operational security.
Disciplined infantry trained and equipped to win fights fast—preferably before anyone knows they were there.
Corporate or contracted security under Enclave influence—useful hands for holding doors and doing deniable work.
Special-ops style trooper assigned to high-priority security or strike missions—tight discipline, heavy kit, little sympathy.
The brain trust: weapons R&D, biological projects, and medical programs—brilliant work done behind locked doors and moral blinders.
Keeps aircraft, reactors, and armor from becoming expensive coffins—maintenance is survival at Enclave scale.
The voice in the static: relays encrypted orders and keeps the chain of command intact across hostile ground.
Naval service in a world that forgot shipyards—keeps vessels running and watch rotations tight.
Commands maritime assets and logistics, enforcing discipline where one mistake can sink an entire operation.
Aircraft operator with high skill and higher value—often the first target once shooting starts.
Protective detail and internal security: guarding leadership, vetting threats, and ensuring ‘loyalty’ stays more than a slogan.
The Institute’s leader, steering policy and priorities while balancing internal factions and surface risk.
Designs and maintains synth systems and robotics infrastructure—the clean hands behind the Institute’s dirtiest reach.
Tracks down escaped synths and manages recovery operations—bureaucracy with teeth and a long memory.
Works on genetics and life sciences that keep the Institute advanced—and ethically unsettling.
High-end research into power, materials, and theory that makes the Institute feel like a different century.
Maintenance crew for power, water, and structure—because even utopias collapse without a wrench in hand.
Elite hunter deployed to the surface for retrieval and enforcement—efficient, relentless, and hard to stop.
Quiet asset topside feeding the Institute information—often invisible until the day they ruin someone’s life.
The rallying symbol and strategic head, rebuilding a volunteer militia into something that can actually defend settlements.
Senior commander translating intent into action—organizing patrols, defenses, and rapid response.
Citizen-soldier who shows up with whatever works, because someone has to stand between raiders and home.
Network heartbeat: broadcasts distress calls, relays orders, and keeps scattered settlements feeling connected.
Keeps weapons and supplies moving so volunteer courage is backed by ammo and food.
Crew and capability that turns settlement defense into real battlefield influence—when the guns are built and fed.
Regional economic authority. Power through contracts, not force. Comparable influence to minor NCR administrators.
Controls movement of goods and timing. Operational leverage without direct coercion.
Financial control equals indirect power. Non-combatant but strategically decisive; higher long-term impact than guards.
Trade-focused role under corporate oversight. Less autonomy than independent traders.
Movement and survival along trade routes. More structure than independent caravans.
Defensive violence only. Protects assets rather than projecting dominance.
Personal and asset protection. Slightly lower authority and autonomy than caravan guards.
Information gatekeeper role. Soft power through access control; low violence, high leverage.
Trusted (or desperate) runner moving parcels across the Mojave, where ‘delivery’ can become legend or a shallow grave.
Keeps routes and dropboxes functioning, assigns jobs, and tries to keep couriers alive long enough to be paid.
Holds the tribe together through strength, deals, and blood ties—deciding whether the Khans raid, trade, or move on.
A trusted voice steering the Chieftain through politics, rivalries, and the consequences of old grudges.
Sells muscle for caps, acting as hired guns when the tribe needs supplies more than pride.
Fast hits, intimidation, and taking what others can’t protect—the classic Khan reputation.
Keeps weapons, leather, and scavenged gear functional—because a tribe lives or dies by its kit.
Moves chems between buyers and makers, dodging patrols and rivals in the wasteland’s most dangerous supply chain.
Street-level chem seller turning desperation into caps and keeping the tribe’s dirtiest economy alive.
Settles disputes and punishes betrayal—more tribal justice than courtroom procedure.
Eyes ahead of the pack—finds routes, threats, and opportunities before the tribe commits.
Oral tradition keeper who turns loss, pride, and exile into something the tribe can carry.
Sets the humanitarian mission: education, medicine, and knowledge—often in conflict with the wasteland’s power games.
Keeps clinics running: supplies, schedules, records, and the thankless work that makes charity actually work.
Studies old-world texts and new-world realities, turning scraps of knowledge into practical improvements.
Investigates disease, agriculture, tech salvage, and conditions on the ground to guide better aid.
Advanced medical provider operating with limited tech and high caseloads, trying to keep ‘civilization’ from bleeding out.
Frontline care—triage and field treatment—keeping people alive long enough to reach a proper clinic.
Literacy and skills training—because the Followers know bullets don’t rebuild societies, but education sometimes does.
Junior Archivist is a supporting role within Followers of the Apocalypse, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.
Probationary Initiate is a supporting role within Followers of the Apocalypse, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.
General support staff: translating notes, hauling supplies, and doing whatever keeps the mission moving.
Leader (Field Cell / Local Chapter) is a supporting role within Followers of the Apocalypse, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.
Top-tier command overseeing large-scale deployments and resources.
High command figure coordinating broad strategy and major assets.
Senior leader overseeing complex engagements and regional objectives.
Runs major operations and holds authority over substantial forces.
Officer-level coordinator balancing orders with realities on the ground.
Operational lead managing multiple squads and mission planning.
Runs unit discipline and tactics, turning contracts into completed objectives.
Small-team leader expected to keep squads effective and obedient.
Entry soldier doing patrols and guard duty, learning that ‘professional’ still means lethal.
New blood pulled into a professional merc machine—trained fast, deployed faster.
Recon specialist identifying targets and risks before the main force commits.
Gunner (General Operative) is a senior authority figure within Gunners, responsible for setting policy, directing operations, and enforcing the organisation’s priorities in the wasteland.
The one voice that matters in Nellis—decides who gets welcomed, who gets shelled, and how loudly the tribe warns outsiders off.
Maintains guns, generators, and the Boomers’ precious stockpile—because one broken part can mean one dead friend.
Keeps the Boomers healthy with a mix of vault-bred knowledge and wasteland improvisation, often with limited supplies.
Passes on literacy, history, and practical skills so the tribe stays sharp—and remembers why outsiders aren’t trusted.
Perimeter security and readiness; at Nellis, ‘warning shots’ tend to be artillery.
The tribe’s historian who preserves and recites Boomer history—keeping identity intact through story and ritual memory.
Directs chem-crazed violence toward profit and turf, barely keeping the pack from turning on itself.
Top boss among Fiends—more feared, more unstable, usually more heavily armed.
Raider shock trooper living for the rush, the chems, and the sound of someone else’s panic.
Foot soldier of chaos—dangerous precisely because self-preservation isn’t always part of the plan.
Holds a vicious little tribe together through fear and hunger, pointing them at softer prey.
A taboo made routine—survives (or indulges) by eating people, turning horror into ‘just another meal.’
Cult-tinged authority figure using ritual and fear to bind raiders into a ‘faith.’
Keeps rites, symbols, and intimidation theatrics alive—belief used as a weapon.
Zealot title for the kind of raider who speaks threats like scripture and acts accordingly.
Fast, brutal ambusher working routes and canyons, thriving on terror and surprise.
Warrior of the Snake is a frontline role for Vipers, focused on protection, patrols, raids, or direct combat—doing the dangerous work that keeps territory held and enemies wary.
Cult-tinged authority figure using ritual and fear to bind raiders into a ‘faith.’
Keeps rites, symbols, and intimidation theatrics alive—belief used as a weapon.
Zealot title for the kind of raider who speaks threats like scripture and acts accordingly.
Fast, brutal ambusher working routes and canyons, thriving on terror and surprise.
Warrior of the Snake is a frontline role for Vipers, focused on protection, patrols, raids, or direct combat—doing the dangerous work that keeps territory held and enemies wary.
Runs a street gang with style and swagger—more turf and attitude than grand ideology.
Rank-and-file tough: pomade, bravado, and a willingness to throw down over respect.
Power broker with chips as weapons—controls security, profits, and the illusion of paradise behind the gate.
Keeps the games moving and the house winning, smiling while reading every twitch of a gambler’s hand.
A heavily irradiated ghoul—walking hazard and living symbol—often treated with reverence among true believers.
Rare specialist chasing impossible dreams of rockets and ascension, translating old-world aerospace into wasteland reality.
Keeps the sect’s equipment and transport functional, because even pilgrims need working machines.
Devotee of the journey—faith, radiation, and hope welded into purpose.
The one who can keep super mutants aligned under a goal instead of letting violence become the only language.
Stealth-obsessed mutant, unpredictable and dangerous—often living with fractured minds and hard paranoia.
Heavy-hitting brute survivor living by strength, scavenging, and rough community.
Charismatic leader whose rule is built on identity, respect, and keeping Freeside from collapsing completely.
Enforcer and community muscle: backs the King’s decisions and keeps outsiders honest.
More important than it sounds—maintains the Kings’ look, reinforcing belonging through style.
Runs a convict gang with dynamite and spite, turning stolen explosives into leverage.
Second-in-command managing crews, extortion, and discipline—keeping chaos pointed outward.
Rank-and-file criminal: theft, threats, and violence with a prison-born code.
Personal protection for leadership, because betrayals are common and bullets are cheap.
Controls access to a camp or hideout, deciding who walks in and who gets turned away at gunpoint.
Raw material of the gang—desperate, angry, and ready to follow anyone offering food and revenge.
Leads routes, hires guards, and makes the calls when the trail turns ugly.
Protection detail for people and cargo, paid in caps and risk.
Sells on the move, negotiates at stops, and keeps profit alive despite losses.
Keeper of beliefs and taboos, guiding the tribe through story, ritual, and restraint.
Healer and mystic figure blending medicine, ritual, and social authority.
Outsider bringing religion and instruction—sometimes helpfully, sometimes disruptively.
Defender of the tribe using simple weapons, stealth, and terrain knowledge.
Path expert leading safely through water sources, canyons, and dangers outsiders can’t read.
Life-bringer and healer protecting mothers and infants in a world that doesn’t forgive weakness.

role: War Chief of the Dead Horses
notes: Leads fighters and sets war policy, balancing survival with honor and tradition.
Tribal fighter trained by harsh land and constant threats.
Ranges ahead and watches borders, reading tracks like text.
Stealth hunter and ambusher who uses terrain and patience to strike first.
A member shaped by New Canaan influence—faith carried into hard country.
Community member shaped by tradition, subsistence, and the tribe’s laws.
Directs raids and warfare, pushing aggression as identity and policy.
Morale and signal role—sound used to intimidate, rally, and coordinate.
Title tied to torches and fire—signals, burns, and terror in the dark.
Raider specializing in cruelty as a tactic and a reputation.
Heavy hitter who solves problems up close and leaves warnings behind.
Demolition-minded raiders who break defenses, set traps, and exploit weak points.
Rank-and-file members shaped by raiding culture and hard land.

role: Head Chief First Researcher of Labs
notes: Senior authority coordinating major research efforts across labs and facilities.

role: First Head Chief Researcher of Mineralogy and Medical Sciences
notes: Oversees materials and medical research—two fields that become terrifying together.

role: Chief Head Researcher of Logistical Operations and Ideology
notes: Chief Head Researcher of Logistical Operations and Ideology supports Think Tank through technical skill—maintaining equipment, infrastructure, or research that keeps the faction functioning and competitive.
Oversees animal experimentation, turning living creatures into ‘projects.’
Sound specialist researching resonance and sonic tech that can make the air itself feel unsafe.
Builds autonomous systems and maintains machines that outlast common sense—and sometimes outlast ethics.
Top boss with a lounge-act smile—runs the family, the casino, and the violence behind the velvet rope.
The fixer who makes problems disappear quietly and efficiently.
Manages signature acts, schedules, and image control to keep the shine on.
Recruits and contracts performers—fresh faces keep the casino alive.
Velvet voice for smoky rooms—an act that sells the Strip’s illusion.
Keeps the casino mood polished; music is part of the brand.
Stage performer selling glamour, distraction, and the feeling nothing bad exists outside the lights.
Stage talent that keeps the crowd distracted while real deals happen in back rooms.
Works crowds outside the spotlight, earning caps and rumors with jokes.
A performer pulled into Vegas glitz—sometimes protected, sometimes exploited, always watched.
Crime head wrapped in casino legitimacy—gambling out front, power plays out back.
Holds the keys to money flow, security, and the Strip’s ‘legal’ face.
Second-in-command handling operations, discipline, and succession politics.
Runs crews and enforces orders, managing violence like a business process.
Trusted fixer who keeps the boss insulated from mess.
Street muscle: threats, beatings, collections.
Button Man is a supporting role within Omertas, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.
Moves illegal firepower through controlled spaces without drawing too much attention.
Handles bombs and sabotage, turning infrastructure into leverage.
The nightmare tool—intimidation through cruelty, used when fear is the message.
Originator of the Society’s identity: etiquette, exclusivity, and secrets that stain linen.
Front-of-house authority managing guests and appearances so the illusion never slips.
Controls staff and operations to keep the experience flawless and scandal invisible.
Right-hand Man is a supporting role within White Glove Society, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.
Culinary authority for indulgence and spectacle, where appetites can cross lines.
Feeds secrets upward—because in the Ultra-Luxe, gossip is currency.
Rank-and-file member: refined exterior, cold interior, loyal to the brand and its hidden rules.
Charismatic head of a power-armor greaser crew—style, swagger, and a love of tuned-up steel.
Watches the garage and the crew’s gear, because power armor attracts trouble like a beacon.
Hunts parts and salvage to keep suits running and the crew thriving.
Friendly face who sells the vibe and keeps strangers from wandering into the wrong room.
Core member—grease, slang, and a personal relationship with their armor.
Trades parts and gear, turning salvage into caps and caps into upgrades.
Keeps the crew’s culture alive through music and style—identity matters as much as plating.
Commands a raider crew built around fire and brutality, treating heat and metal like religion.
Member of a violent gang that survives by taking—often with cruelty as a signature.
Mayor is a senior authority figure within Diamond City Security, responsible for setting policy, directing operations, and enforcing the organisation’s priorities in the wasteland.
Gatekeeper is a supporting role within Diamond City Security, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.
Security Officer is a frontline role for Diamond City Security, focused on protection, patrols, raids, or direct combat—doing the dangerous work that keeps territory held and enemies wary.
Security Guard is a frontline role for Diamond City Security, focused on protection, patrols, raids, or direct combat—doing the dangerous work that keeps territory held and enemies wary.
Local leader coordinating community defense and basic governance.
Makes rules stick through intimidation and decisive force.
Protects leadership from raiders—or from angry locals.
Patrols and alarms—early warning and deterrence.
Editor/publisher deciding what runs and what gets buried.
Leads deep investigations connecting dots powerful people want unconnected.
Chases leads and turns danger into print—because truth sells, and so does scandal.
Writes features and editorials shaping public opinion one page at a time.
Street seller pushing headlines for caps and rumors.
Keeps the press alive, enabling information to spread through the city.
Casework in a broken world: missing persons, murders, and truths that get you shot.
Field legwork: interviews, surveillance, and digging up details that crack a case.
Front desk and organization—keeps clients coming and the detective functional.
Caravan Boss is a senior authority figure within Stockton’s Caravan Company, responsible for setting policy, directing operations, and enforcing the organisation’s priorities in the wasteland.
Trader keeps goods, money, and supplies moving for Stockton’s Caravan Company, handling the practical logistics that decide whether a community thrives or collapses.
Caravaneer keeps goods, money, and supplies moving for Stockton’s Caravan Company, handling the practical logistics that decide whether a community thrives or collapses.
Guard is a frontline role for Stockton’s Caravan Company, focused on protection, patrols, raids, or direct combat—doing the dangerous work that keeps territory held and enemies wary.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: Senior spiritual authority setting doctrine and directing the faithful.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: Receives sins and doubts, guiding believers back to Atom’s glow through counsel and ritual.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: Elite militant devotee leading zealots and embodying fanatic resolve.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: True believer willing to suffer and kill for the faith.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: Nurturing authority figure offering care framed as holy duty.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: Brother / Sister is a supporting role within Church of the Children of Atom, contributing to day-to-day survival and operations in a world where every job can turn lethal fast.

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: General adherent whose identity is bound to radiation’s ‘blessing.’

faction: Church of the Children of Atom
notes: High Confessor’s Guard is a senior authority figure within Church of the Children of Atom, responsible for setting policy, directing operations, and enforcing the organisation’s priorities in the wasteland.
Authority derived from lineage rather than leadership; insulated from consequence; highly detached from wasteland reality.
Operational support role with partial knowledge; loyalty-driven ethical ambiguity; greater autonomy than cult acolytes.
Protective violence specialist; loyalty to individuals rather than ideology; less indoctrinated than cult-aligned guards.

Power via fear, spectacle, and dominance; less strategic than Legion or Omertas leaders; higher volatility than structured crime bosses.

Top authority over multiple raider gangs—rules through spectacle, brutality, and control of resources.

Mid-tier raider authority; relies on intimidation and opportunism; limited long-term planning.

Boss by violence and charisma, keeping predators aimed at outsiders instead of each other.

Sadism-forward raider subtype; violence as identity; distinct from Fiends via intent over impulse.

Cult-like killer who treats cruelty as identity and intimidation as art.

Group-dominance driven raider; hierarchy through physicality; lower cognition than Operators.

Animal-themed raider valuing dominance, showmanship, and pack hierarchy.

Profit-oriented raider; higher planning depth; bridge between raiders and crime syndicates.

Profit-driven ‘professionals’—less chaos, more cold calculation.

Tech-fixated raider; mechanical dominance replaces ideology; distinct from Atom Cats via coercion.

Raider-tech scavver obsessed with robots and scrap, using machinery to dominate.

Arena-conditioned violence specialist; aggression normalized through spectacle.

Arena-minded thug tied to pit-fight culture: violence as entertainment and control.

Baseline wasteland aggressor; lowest structure, highest prevalence; critical lower-bound comparator.

Rank-and-file thief and killer living by fear and fast gains.

Authority rooted in perceived necessity; moral compromise justified as survival; less transparent than Diamond City leadership.

Community leader maintaining a ‘safe’ image—often with rules that cut deeper than they first appear.

Ethical detachment via rationalization; similar intellect to Institute researchers; lower abstraction, higher guilt suppression.

Research role tied to the settlement’s hidden agenda—knowledge used as justification.

Medical authority constrained by ideology; care filtered through suspicion and testing.

Provides healthcare—sometimes with compromises depending on what the town hides.

Security-first mindset; obedience driven by fear and doctrine rather than law.

Enforces security and keeps outsiders at arm’s length.

Routine surveillance role; trust erosion normalized; lower authority than guards.

Patrols and monitors residents and visitors alike.
Violence used as preventive control; less restrained than civic police, more structured than raiders.

Cognitive bias amplification role; reinforces paranoia feedback loop; low authority, high narrative impact.

Suspicious voice connecting dots—sometimes right, often ignored until it’s too late.

Civilian under constant suspicion; agency suppressed by fear-driven governance.

Ordinary citizen living under strict order and constant scrutiny.

Trade constrained by ideology; commerce secondary to security doctrine.

Trades with visitors—controlled, cautious, and watched.

Surface-normalcy role; masks underlying paranoia and control.

Friendly face selling sweetness—part of the settlement’s curated ‘normal.’

Information relay under surveillance; mobility allowed but tightly controlled.

Moves information and orders—fast, quiet, careful.

Authority via organization and fear; less ideological than Omertas bosses; higher operational discipline than raider leaders.

Runs the operation like a pre-war crime family: suits, guns, and leverage.

Day-to-day operational authority; less public-facing than Mob Boss; higher planning depth than Lieutenants.

Senior organizer controlling territory, jobs, and enforcement.

Operational executor and trusted intermediary; balances enforcement with coordination.

Trusted fixer coordinating jobs and keeping the boss insulated.
Mid-level command role; supervises crews and contracts with limited autonomy.

Contract killer / enforcer; less volatile than Raiders; more disciplined than Omertas thugs.

Standard soldier: tommy-gun attitude, hard loyalty, disposable status.

General criminal operative; muscle and intimidation with moderate discipline.

Armed foot soldier doing collections, intimidation, and hits.

Aspirational criminal identity; lower competence, higher risk; internal lower-bound comparator.

Low-tier hanger-on trying to earn respect and a piece of the action.

Revenue-generation role; risk balanced between supply chains and enforcement exposure.

Pushes chems through controlled channels, profiting off addiction.

Legitimate-front criminal role; higher social camouflage; reduced direct violence exposure.

Legit front or real enterprise—either way, money and influence are the point.

Authority via fabricated knowledge; less violent than Children of Atom zealots; higher social manipulation than scientific factions.

Charismatic authority promising transcendence through a blend of pseudo-science and faith.

Operational authority beneath the Cult Leader; manages doctrine enforcement and internal compliance.

Keeps the cult organized, recruits aligned, and dissent handled.

Genuine technical competence misapplied; cognitive dissonance role; contrasts with OSI engineers.

Maintains the cult’s ‘ascension’ hardware—dangerous tech plus dangerous belief.

Charismatic propaganda asset; belief reinforcement through celebrity and image rather than authority.

Celebrity used as recruitment bait—glamour repurposed as devotion.

Recruitment and belief-spreading role; persuasion without formal authority.

Recruiter spreading doctrine to new marks.

General adherent role; belief-driven identity with limited agency.

Rank-and-file believer chasing meaning in a harsh world.

Entry-level believer; highest susceptibility to influence; lowest authority and stability.

Fresh convert being shaped into loyal labor and loyal faith.

Executive authority in a failing system; decisions prioritise continuity over consent; less legitimacy than NCR Presidents, higher urgency.

Executive authority claim—symbol of continuity even as the world refuses to cooperate.

Procedural authority during systemic breakdown; coordination-focused; higher diplomacy than executive roles.

A senior official role in a stopgap government trying to keep laws and legitimacy alive after the bombs.

Legislative coordination role; bridges executive urgency and civil process under emergency conditions.

Political organizer role keeping the emergency legislature moving despite collapse and chaos.

Enforces emergency law; violence justified as containment; more authority than local police, less than military command.

Security head trying to enforce law with limited manpower and overwhelming threats.

Supreme interpreter of prophecy; authority through revelation, not force; higher metaphysical certainty than Children of Atom leaders.

Top male clerical authority directing major rites.

Co-equal visionary leader; spiritual counterpart to the High Priest; reinforces dualistic authority within doctrine.

Top female clerical authority directing major rites.

Visionary authority without governance; high emotional influence; less organizational control than High Priests.

Visionary interpreting signs and steering big decisions.

High ritual authority within female priest hierarchy; mediates prophecy to followers; symbolic continuity role.

Senior priestess role, often closest to the Prophet’s inner circle.

Ritual practitioner; interprets signs and omens; less authority than prophets, more spiritual than operational.

Clergy role conducting ceremonies and guiding worship.

Custodian of long-standing beliefs; maintains orthodoxy; senior but not visionary.

Senior authority and keeper of tradition and interpretation.

Interpretive authority without command; comparable to Sorrows Shamans but dogmatic; high narrative influence.

Council figure offering guidance, lore, and judgment.

Field witness role; collects signs of divine presence; low authority but vital to cult validation cycles.

Watches for omens and tracks movement—spiritual surveillance.

Translates divine messages for ritual or doctrine; functions between visionary and clerical strata.

Translates visions and symbols into doctrine and orders.

Claimed recipients of revelation; authority through perceived enlightenment; less organisational control than Priests.

Title for one who claims enlightenment or contact—often treated with reverence.

Elite believers marked for destiny; higher social status than Awoken; faith replaces meritocracy.

Marked member believed selected for special purpose.

Transitional role toward higher revelation; self-sacrifice normalized; initiatory elite function.

Believer elevated through ritual status, treated as spiritually ‘closer’ to revelation.

Faith aspirant role; curiosity over conviction; highly vulnerable to indoctrination.

Searches for omens and relics, reading the ruins like scripture.

Mid-level believer; executes doctrine rather than authors it; ideological enforcement without command.

Dedicated follower tasked with service and spreading doctrine.
General initiated membership; communal identity reinforced through ritual participation.

Rank-and-file believer; faith outweighs self-preservation; higher cohesion than Raiders.

Active practitioner devoted to the Mothman’s signs—believing mystery is proof.

Pre-initiate observer; minimal authority; highest susceptibility to narrative capture.

Newcomer proving devotion before being trusted with deeper rites.

Faith-bound shock enforcer; violence framed as divine mandate; disciplined but not strategic.

Militant title—faith expressed through violence and vengeance.

Extreme violence executor; destruction as sacred duty; lower restraint than Wrathwings.

Enforcer role embodying terror as devotion.

Executes ritualized purification; violence framed as mercy; high moral dissonance role.

Ritual authority focused on purification and maintaining holy spaces.
Absolute authority within a sealed system; moral agency constrained by corporate doctrine; comparable authority to Institute Director with lower abstraction.
Research-first mindset; ethics subordinated to experiment design; less autonomy than Think Tank scientists.
System maintenance under secrecy; higher practical skill than Scientists; lower ideological buy-in.
Enforces containment rather than justice; violence justified as order preservation; comparable to Covenant guards with less paranoia.
Subject rather than agent; identity shaped by environment; baseline civilian-under-control comparator.
Corporate evangelist role; high persuasion with low accountability; pre-war social manipulation archetype.

Strategic scientific leadership balancing politics, funding, and ethics; less absolute authority than Institute Director.

Sets OSI priorities—research agendas aimed at survival, stability, and state power.

Senior project authority; translates institutional ethics into research execution.

Top scientific authority coordinating labs, approvals, and priority work.

Experienced investigator; strong methodological rigor under ethical constraints.

Experienced investigator leading projects and mentoring staff.

Developing scientist; high supervision and low authority.

Entry scientist learning to do real work with scarce resources and high stakes.

General research role; balances discovery with regulatory compliance.

General research role across medicine, tech, and environmental survival.

Implementation-focused technical role; converts theory into systems.

Builds and maintains devices and infrastructure that keep society functional.

Ecological and agricultural specialist; strong humanitarian crossover.

Works agriculture and plant science, chasing food security in hostile soil.

Knowledge dissemination and mentorship role; high social-cognitive influence.

Academic authority shaping training and theory behind OSI work.

Patient-first medical science; strong contrast to Vault-Tec experimentation.

Medical specialist applying science directly to human survival.

Applied science under contract; higher risk tolerance; bridge between academia and wasteland pragmatism.

Outsider specialist hired for niche work—useful, but never fully trusted.

Community survival role; low agency and high environmental dependence. Baseline comparator for all civilian roles.

Builds something permanent and dares the world to try taking it.
Urban-adjacent civilian with moderate social exposure and limited self-defense capability.

Food-production specialist; survival-oriented with minimal authority or mobility.

Turns dirt into survival, defending crops like they’re gold.
Lowest-agency agricultural role; physical endurance over autonomy.

Violence is instrumental rather than ideological; bridges civilian and combat archetypes.

Tracks meat and danger, living by patience and a steady aim.

High environmental risk tolerance; opportunistic survival behavior.

Digs through ruins for anything useful, gambling life against scrap value.

Mobile civilian commerce role; moderate manipulation and adaptability.

Buys low, sells high, and knows which roads are lying to you.

Controls essential survival resource; higher leverage than general traders.

Sells the wasteland’s true currency: clean water, guarded like treasure.

Information nexus and morale role; social influence without formal authority.

Runs a neutral ground where rumors travel and violence is always one drink away.

Civilian contract killer; higher autonomy than mercenaries. Bridges Wastelanders and Talon-style archetypes.

Paid violence with paperwork—brings in targets dead or alive depending on the contract.

Authority through coordination and charisma; balances logistics with performance. Less coercive than casino owners.

Manages the show, schedules, and security—because crowds are both profit and threat.

Provides care under itinerant conditions; combines humanitarian focus with performance economy.

Patchwork medicine keeping performers, workers, and visitors from dying in the funhouse.

Keeps rides and systems functional; practical competence over social influence.

Fixes rides, generators, and booths—keeping the lights on in a dead world.

Front-facing service role; emotional regulation and safety awareness over authority.

Keeps attractions running (or at least not killing everyone immediately).

Small-scale trade within entertainment economy; relies on charm and repetition.

Sells whatever moves—food, junk, toys, chems—caps are caps.

Iconic consumable sales role; brand recognition substitutes for authority.

Sells bottles, nostalgia, and sugar—because the brand outlived the world.

Symbolic value sales; nostalgia-driven transactions.

Peddles souvenirs and branded salvage to anyone with caps and sentimentality.

High emotional signaling role; distraction and mood control.

Entertains with a grin that looks a little too much like a scream in the wasteland.

Performative mysticism; emotional reassurance over belief enforcement.

Turns cold reading and old myths into comfort—or warnings people ignore.

Curated intimacy and nostalgia; symbolic romance facilitation.

Runs a themed attraction built on irony—romance packaged for survivalists.

Manages reward-based distraction systems; engagement over authority.

Maintains arcade machines and prize counters, turning play into profit.
Probability theater; excitement management role.

Symbolic law enforcement parody; contrasts with real sheriffs via lack of coercion.

Stage-law persona selling frontier fantasy with scripted authority.

Pure symbolic morale asset; zero authority, maximum recognizability.

Costume performer embodying the park’s cheerful lie.

Companion brand symbol to Cappy; interchangeable morale projection role.

Same gig, same heatstroke risk, different oversized head.
Authority through competence and trust. Less political than NCR officers; lower ruthlessness than Talon Company commanders.
Primary tactical executor; maintains cohesion under pressure with greater field exposure than the Leader.
Core combat and reconnaissance operator; high autonomy and competence with minimal ideology.
Provides concentrated firepower; balances suppression with maneuver, less reckless than raider heavies.
Sensors, communications, and field tech under fire; distinct from pure engineers through combat exposure.
Manages logistics under combat conditions; higher autonomy than NCR equivalents with direct mission impact.
Provides trauma care in hostile environments; strong moral anchor with higher exposure than civilian medics.

Strategic authority rooted in contracts and fear. Less unit loyalty than Reilly’s Rangers; higher brutality tolerance than Gunners officers.

Controls contracts and strategy—turning violence into a business model.

Localized command authority focused on payout efficiency. Less strategic scope than the Commander role.

Top authority behind operations—money, fear, and control.

Rank-and-file combatant. Violence as occupation rather than ideology; more disciplined than Raiders, less than Gunners.

Paid soldier with a ruthless reputation—mission first, conscience never.

Targeted elimination specialist. Higher precision than Talon Mercs; less restraint than NCR covert operators.

Specialist killer used for targeted eliminations and intimidation hits.

Demolition and intimidation specialist. Violence scaled for impact; higher recklessness than Gunners engineers.

Uses bombs and traps to end fights quickly and brutally.

Authority through charisma and fear projection. More posturing than actual dominance; significantly less lethal than wasteland gang leaders.

Heads a vault-bred gang that treats swagger like survival and loyalty like currency.

Identity reinforcement role. Group belonging outweighs individual ambition; comparable to Greasers with less external exposure and risk.

Follows the crew code: attitude, intimidation, and sticking together in tight corridors.

Cultural symbol role. Non-violent influence via appearance and ritual grooming; maintains gang cohesion and shared identity.

Keeps the look sharp—because image is half the gang’s power.

Civil leader balancing order and reconstruction. Authority derived from coordination and stability, not coercion.

Coordinates teams for building, defense, or supply runs.

Official liaison and negotiator. Balances trade, diplomacy, and stability within regional politics.

Diplomatic face handling trade, alliances, and disputes.

Baseline community role within Foundation society. Focused on survival through structure and shared labor.

Everyday resident rebuilding a town with sweat and stubborn hope.

Expands the Foundation’s frontier. Balances personal survival with collective growth.

New arrival helping expand territory and resources beyond the walls.

Entry-level tradesperson developing essential skills under mentorship. Core of Foundation’s self-sufficiency pipeline.

Learns a trade under senior hands—skills are inheritance now.

Skilled laborer maintaining daily production. Supports infrastructure with craft expertise and efficiency.

Produces goods and repairs essential items for the community.

Competent independent craftsman. Bridges production and leadership tiers within Foundation’s hierarchy.

Competent tradesperson trusted with bigger jobs and leadership tasks.

Highest skilled artisan; oversees apprentices and journeymen. Central to Foundation’s technical reputation.

Top-tier metalworker producing high-quality tools and protection.

Operates and maintains machinery crucial for infrastructure; technical backbone of Foundation industry.

Runs tools and machinery, keeping production alive.

Designs and oversees mechanical and civil systems. High technical literacy, moderate authority.

Designs and maintains infrastructure, power, and defenses.

Protective combatant for civilian areas. Violence as defense, not domination; disciplined and community-trusted.

Protects the settlement from raids and internal threats.

Manages entry and safety protocols. Emphasizes observation and restraint over confrontation.

Controls entry, checks threats, acts as first responder.

Responsible for food and raw material gathering. Operates beyond settlement perimeter with moderate autonomy.

Hunts plants, salvage, and supplies beyond safe bounds.

Operates at the edges of civilization. Balances survival independence with loyalty to Foundation’s structure.

Works the outskirts—foraging, scouting, living closer to danger.

Strategic authority and ideological guardian. Oversees doctrine, secrecy, and long-term mission direction. High symbolic legitimacy with restrained use of force.

Senior leader overseeing doctrine, operations, and secrecy.

Fully realised covert operative. Combines ritual identity with intelligence tradecraft and targeted violence. High autonomy and field competence.

Symbolic head embodying the order’s identity and direction.

Responsible for recruitment, training, and doctrinal transmission. Shapes identity and loyalty more than conducting frontline operations.

Trainer authority shaping new members into capable operatives.

Aspirant operative undergoing ideological and practical testing. Positioned between civilian identity and covert commitment.

Operative who gathers intel and acts on missions in the shadows.

Early-stage member. Limited authority and exposure, focused on learning operational security and symbolic discipline.

Early-stage member proving skill and discretion.

Lowest formal tier. Identity adoption and trust assessment phase with minimal operational responsibility.

New recruit learning secrets, technique, and the order’s purpose.

Provides mission-critical technical, forensic, and gadget support. Lower visibility, high operational impact.

Maintains gear and devices that enable covert work.

Strategic coordination authority. Balances ethics, triage, and risk. Less coercive than government executives.

Top authority coordinating the faction’s direction and priorities.

Veteran field authority acting as a stabilising node in chaos. High trust role with elevated burnout risk.

Experienced leader guiding teams and setting standards.

Pre-service candidate undergoing evaluation. Motivation present, experience limited.

Applicant under evaluation—training, temperament, and readiness tested.

Active service volunteer. Performs essential support and response tasks under supervision.

Entry responder helping with relief and support tasks.

Core operational responder. Broad capability across rescue, aid, and stabilisation tasks.

Full member providing aid, rescue, and defense when disasters hit.

Law enforcement under emergency mandate. De-escalation prioritised over punishment.

Law enforcement arm maintaining order during crises.

Handles serious crimes during collapse conditions. Investigative focus maintained despite instability.

Investigates serious incidents—murders, corruption, organized threats.

Hazard-zone specialist operating in extreme environments. Courage under environmental threat.

Elite combat-and-rescue responder trained for high-threat operations under fire.

Frontline medical responder providing trauma care under hostile conditions.

Emergency medicine specialist handling trauma and triage.

Leads medical operations and triage policy. High ethical load and system-wide impact.

Oversees medical operations, training, and clinical policy.

Sustained patient care and recovery support. High empathy, critical continuity role.

Clinical support and patient care under pressure.

Trauma mitigation and mental health stabilisation. High empathy, minimal aggression; unique cross-faction stabiliser.

Treats trauma and crisis stress, keeping people from breaking when the world does.

Infrastructure survival authority. Decisions determine long-term habitability. Higher systemic impact than combat leaders.

Leads infrastructure repair and technical planning.

Resource triage under scarcity. Moral stress role determining allocation priorities.

Controls supply distribution and logistics.

Keeps vehicles and generators operational under pressure. Practical survival multiplier.

Keeps vehicles, generators, and tools operational.
Deploys automation in dangerous environments. Bridges OSI-grade science and field pragmatism.

Public health linchpin. Failure results in slow systemic collapse.

Keeps clean water systems running—the job that saves more lives than bullets.

Sustains morale and health through reliable nutrition under scarcity.

Feeds teams and civilians—morale and survival in one ladle.

Acquires and distributes supplies under active threat conditions.

Distributes supplies and organizes deliveries.

Protects survival-critical logistics. Defensive violence only; not territorial.

Protects shipments—because aid is a target.

Maintains communication and supply continuity across unstable terrain.

Moves messages and small critical cargo quickly.

Forward awareness and early warning. Threat detection prioritised over engagement.

Recon and route-safety specialist for teams moving into unknown danger.

Teaches defensive combat doctrine. Violence framed as protection, not domination. Less aggressive than mercenary trainers.

Instructs defensive tactics, weapons handling, and team movement.

Cross-discipline preparedness authority. Builds resilience under chaos. High institutional knowledge role.

Teaches protocols for fires, floods, attacks, and evacuations.

Generalist instructor role. Knowledge transfer across responder disciplines.

General instruction role across rescue skills and procedures.

Immediate threat neutralisation. Defensive aggression with higher discipline than raiders, lower lethality than elite military.

Security for fast-deploy teams in dangerous zones.

Trauma care under fire. Balances speed and compassion. Higher stress than standard medics.

Medic embedded with rapid response, treating casualties in active threats.

Locates survivors and hazards. Endurance and situational awareness over direct confrontation.

Locates survivors, scouts hazards, extracts people from disaster zones.

Sustainment of defensive force. Violence indirectly enabled; ethical tension role.

Produces and maintains ammo supply for defensive operations.

Medical chemistry, detox, and emergency pharmacology. Ethical counterweight to drug dealers with high technical and moral responsibility.

Manages medical chems safely, preventing misuse and shortages.
Regional economic authority. Power through contracts, not force. Comparable influence to minor NCR administrators.
Controls movement of goods and timing. Operational leverage without direct coercion.
Financial control equals indirect power. Non-combatant but strategically decisive; higher long-term impact than guards.
Trade-focused role under corporate oversight. Less autonomy than independent traders.
Movement and survival along trade routes. More structure than independent caravans.
Defensive violence only. Protects assets rather than projecting dominance.
Personal and asset protection. Slightly lower authority and autonomy than caravan guards.
Information gatekeeper role. Soft power through access control; low violence, high leverage.

Strategic criminal authority. Profit and intimidation-driven leadership. Less legitimacy than Crimson Caravan managers.

Runs the energy-weapon business with a sharp smile and sharper accounting—profits first, mercy never.

Face of illicit commerce. Persuasion backed by implicit or explicit threat. Higher danger tolerance than standard merchants.

Sells high-end energy weapons carefully, because one bad customer can end the whole operation.

Violence-as-deterrence role. Precision lethality via advanced energy weapons. More disciplined than raiders, less than military elites.

Store security and intimidation: discourages theft, collects debts, and makes examples when needed.

Contract protection role. Loyalty to payment only. Interchangeable with lower-tier Talon mercenaries.

Contract muscle protecting shipments and storefronts, paid well because the targets are well armed.

Strategic industrial authority. Long-term planning over intimidation. Higher legitimacy than Van Graff managers.

Controls contracts and priorities, deciding which guns get built and who gets cut off.

Customer-facing role. Reputation-sensitive negotiation. Less coercive than Van Graff traders.

Sells firearms and ammo with industrial consistency—because demand never stops in the wasteland.

Craft authority with high technical competence. Violence mediated through engineering.

Crafts, repairs, and improves weapons, turning scrap into reliable firepower.

Procurement and distribution node. High-risk logistics. More strategic and less public-facing than merchants.

Handles procurement—parts, metals, and deals that keep production flowing.

Asset protection role. Defensive violence doctrine. Higher discipline than caravan guards.

Protects the factory and inventory, because the Gun Runners are a walking fortune in metal.

Street-level persuasion specialist. Soft power through repetition and presence. Zero formal authority but high social reach within Freeside.

Hustles attention in the neon shadow of New Vegas—flyers, shouting, deals, and selling hope by the minute.

Hospitality under threat. Conflict-avoidance role. Acts as a civilian continuity anchor within Novac.

Keeps rooms rentable in a town that survives on passing trade—clean sheets, locked doors, and a steady eye on trouble.

Micro-entrepreneur role. Survival through novelty and small-scale trade. Slightly higher agency than Motel Worker.

Sells kitsch and scavenged curios to travelers, turning roadside boredom into caps.

Solo or near-solo law authority. De-escalation preferred, force as last resort. Less reach than NCR Sheriffs, but significantly higher autonomy.

Local lawkeeper trying to make ‘justice’ exist between NCR influence, raider pressure, and the town’s own needs.

Defensive posture only. Violence justified strictly as protection. Less discipline than formal soldiers, but higher moral restraint and stronger community accountability.

Community defense: patrols and checkpoints, protecting locals when outside powers don’t care.

Logistics and civilian trust role. Non-combatant with high survival impact. Comparable to Foundation quartermasters at a smaller, community-focused scale.

Manages supplies and distribution—because militias run on inventory, not speeches.

Internal Brotherhood intelligence enforcement. Loyalty to doctrine over command personalities. Ethical midpoint between NCR Intelligence oversight and Institute SRB-style internal control.

A Brotherhood-linked internal enforcer type—tasked with keeping members loyal and doctrine intact, sometimes with quiet violence.
Strategic coordination and intelligence synthesis role. High ideological commitment with minimal direct violence. Comparable to Order of Mysteries leadership without ritual framing.
Core operational role balancing secrecy, persuasion, and controlled violence. Less lethal than Institute Coursers, higher autonomy than NCR intelligence operatives.
Protection and last-resort force projection role. Violence framed as mission preservation rather than dominance. Less aggressive than mercenary heavies, more restrained than raiders.
Courier and extraction specialist with high exposure and minimal authority. Comparable to Mojave Express couriers with an added ideological risk layer.
Civilian-facing lynchpin role enabling concealment and continuity. High long-term impact through discretion and trust, minimal overt authority.
Cover identity or compartmentalized asset role. Often unaware of full organizational scope. Lowest authority but critical for operational camouflage.
